#SIMConfession15465 Dear #SIMConfession15437,
You are wrong to say no one cares about the the type of degree (distance learning for SIM or local degrees like SUTD).
As a fresh grad, you will be scrutinized. Many positions will be exceptionally tough, or most likely be impossible to secure if you are graduating with a distance learning degree.
Yes,‚Ä¶ More you are correct to say that once you prove yourself, things definitely change.
The gist is this - You WILL be discriminated and start off at least 30%-40% less compared to local grads. You MAY start off the same as a poly grad.
If you prove yourself, however, you MAY close the gap with a local grad and MAY catch up with totally shitty local grads. So the age old question is always this - Is going to a distance learning institution better than just working after you grad from poly?
Same goes for JC students who did terribly. Poly can be much cheaper than a distance learning institution course. Have ROI in mind. (04/07/2019 11:50)

What we fill it up with, ultimately depends on our own individual hunger for growth.
Let‚Äôs not limit ourselves by bothering what others think of us, and start making change and growth from within ourselves.

~final year UOL student"

#SIMConfession14723 Let me explain why Singaporeans hangout after 10pm. When we were 18, everyone's right of passage was to drink alcohol and go to clubs, one cannot happen without the other. Clubs open at 10.30pm++, and get fun at 1am. So everyone was "conditioned" to drink only at 10pm onwards as there was no reason to meet earlier as the clubs‚Ä¶ More would be empty or closed. NOW, here's the problem, most of us never grew out of the 10pm rule, so any drinking or chilling before 10pm will seem odd or weird now even if we are not clubbing. Technically, we could save time and money by starting earlier, but we simply don't. We have no idea why either and it fks up our sleep, body and wallet, but we still do it, because fk common sense. (20/05/2019 19:41)

#SIMConfession13723 Food for thought.
As human it is an interesting observation that we all are inclined towards the comfort of a numerical figure as opposed to say a qualitative dimension way of thinking.
For example lets say I am 1.7m tall. You are 1.9m tall. I weigh 60kg. You weigh 80kg. We feel some sense of relevance to that figure, which‚Ä¶ More means we can somehow make an "imaginary comparision" out of thin air to say " wow you are tall!" Etc.
But lets change this. Im p=4 tall. You are p=10 tall. All of a sudden we lost the sense to relate those figures. Ie they are meaningless. We could not relate "how huge" that figure is. This is what modern economics taught us. Risk aversion comes in a‚Ä¶ More

#SIMConfession12703 UOL is a group of universities not one single entity. In SIM, only UOL Business programmes are external. They are not provided an official University name by ANY of the UOL partners, no one is claiming them. LSE is just the resource supplier, but OFFICIALLY NEVER gave them their name unlike the other Unis. UOL Computing is‚Ä¶ More actually claimed by Goldsmiths, University of London. RMIT is claimed by RMIT. UoB is claimed by the University of Birmingham, UB is claimed by University of Buffalo, New York. The list goes on and on. Simplest way is to see if your Uni has a exchange/transfer program, UOL computing can trasfer to Goldsmith, RMIT can transfer to RMIT, UB can transfer to Buffalo, UoB can transfer to Birmingham. UOL business however, only has SUMMER SCHOOL etc. I repeat, summer school not exchange, they have no parent university to go to. Summer school can be applied by anyone from anywhere in the world upon meeting requirements, as seen by UCLA, UBC, Korea University offered in project 1095. (25/03/2019 19:20)

#SIMConfession12456 To #SIMConfession12418, I am OP from #SIMConfession12261.
I understand your view that we should be appreciative of what we have. I shall stay neutral in my views of his teaching methods. However, one thing I do have to highlight and certainly have to put it out there, his notes are sub-par and this is a severe underestimation.
‚Ä¶ More Recently, i went back to take a peek at his notes on one of the topics i was researching on, his note on that particular topic barely scraped the surface. It is less than 10% out of the entirety of the subject of interest. It is confusing and misleading and certainly not enough for us to write 3 pages of relevant content with. The lecturer that I crashed had much more depth in terms of his materials, teaching style and it facilitates critical thinking and points me(for the very least) in the right direction to carry out further research on the subject at hand. Nonetheless, those are exclusively my opinions. However, you are free to have your opinions as well. Cheers. (16/03/2019 20:57)

Hi all, L here. Hope the exams preparations and submissions have been kind to you all.
Firstly, we are thankful for the support (135 new likes this week!). As a result, we have quite a lot of confessions to‚Ä¶ More post! Do give us a bit of time to adapt to this, and we hope to publish your confessions a day after we receive them.
We are also glad to inform you all that we are now accepting confessions in pictorial form! At the moment we do not have a method for you all to do anonymously (Google forms require you to sign in). In the meantime, if you do not mind us knowing your identity, you can PM us on Facebook, and we will be more than happy to repost it on your behalf.
Do look for a few things that we have coming up, but we are also open to suggestions as well.
After all, regardless of past or present, this is still a page for SIM students. :)

#SIMConfession11960 @11941 One of the things that did not happen. Opposite facing seats are usually on either side of the bus or just a select few in front, with the reverse-facing seat elevated. If you're on those seats aligned on the sides of the bus and the driver jam brake, you fall sideways. If you're on a reverse-facing seat, if the driver‚Ä¶ More jams brake, you fall backwards. If you are on the front-facing seat, yes you do fall forward but because the other seat is elevated, your boobs won't land on the other guy's face. Crotch, maybe.

#SIMConfession11075 Tbh I don't get why Singaporeans find an English "accent" as being snobbish and fake. Our whole lives revolved around american or British media, 18 years of your lives in school taught British English too. The only reason English carried on was because the older generation had to adopt it and their circumstances were different,‚Ä¶ More and children followed. But the new generation technically has zero reason to adopt it.
Singaporeans are the most adaptable due to being multicultural and deep down we all can switch on or off "accents" no matter the language. Yet a few people feel the need to belittle those who has this ability, which 90% of the world is using, judging the way English was meant to be enunciated by the original inventors. You can even hear a bit of a posh/British accent in our grandparents but people looked up to them back then, the language kept degrading as years go by and those who weren't good at it managed to influence everyone else. You don't speak French or Korean but sound Thai do you ? (11/9/2018 15:13)

#SIMConfession10936 Funny how we are still afraid people will judge us in public toilets. Most of us try not to make a sound and be as covert as possible when pooping, like why? Here are a few bullet points:
- We make sure no witnesses see us enter the cubicle in case we make demonly noises.
- We hide our shoes from the gaps in case people identify‚Ä¶ More us once we exit as the "pooper".
- When there is a crowd in the toilet we try to remain as quiet as possible even though no one else knows we're in here.
- When someone knocks your cubicle you gotta do that fake cough so they back off
- We make sure no one is in the toilet once we exit the cubicle like we are some Black ops secret spy, to keep everything low-key.
Why are we embarrassed? It's the toilet, where else am I going to do all these. (10/22/2018 18:18)

#SIMConfession10763 Not sure how many of you followed the journey of the girls in Miss Universe Singapore 2018 but here's my two cents.
This year's theme is on empowering women which I feel is a great theme. However, the first runner up restricts her diet - tofu, bananas and sweet potatoes, and works out around the clock. Sure, no one voiced out‚Ä¶ More because let's face it, she is a pretty face with a hot body, a social influencer and the face of many organizations.
But what happens if we removed the pretty face and the big boobs from the equation. If we look at the bigger picture, is she trying to be a role model to women of all ages to be 'anorexic'? Are we teaching the younger generation to only love their body by looking like her - long legs, flat stomach, big boobs, pretty face etc and eat like her? Or are we teaching girls and women alike to accept them for who they are despite their flaw, despite that number on the scale, despite that extra love handle, as long as they are physically and mentally healthy?
What exactly are we empowering women here at this pageant? (9/19/2018 11:27)

#SIMConfession10729 #LP
New York is three hours ahead of California,
but that doesn't make California slow.
Someone graduated at the age of twenty two,
but waited five years before securing a good job.
Someone became a CEO at twenty five,
and died at fifty.
While another became a CEO at fifty,
and lived to ninety years.
Someone is still single,‚Ä¶ More
while someone else got married.
Obama retired at fifty five,
and Trump started at seventy.
Everyone in this world works based on their time zone.
People around you might seem ahead of you, and some might seem to be behind you.
But everyone is running their own race, in their own time.
Do not envy them and do not mock them.
They are in their time zone, and you are in yours.
Life is about waiting for the right moment to act.
So, Relax!
You're not late.
You're not early.
You are very much on time! ;)
Cheers! (9/11/2018 0:08)

#SIMConfession10172 Dear UOL 1st Year Students,
it's okay to fail your modules, cause your grades don't determine your career path. I myself have taken Maths 1 3 times, and I passed with 99 at my 3rd try. Now I'm holding PhD in Maths and teaching Maths in NTU. I'm not going to reveal my name here but, I just want to say it's okay to fail your mods,‚Ä¶ More just don't give up.
There's always hope. Maths wasn't my forte back in my school days. I picked up maths really quickly after realizing that it can be applied in a lot of ways in real life - such as gambling (you need quick calculations to make your next move). Yes, that's one thing that inspires me to not give up on maths. I've always wanted to be a god of gambler and I am still working on it.
Nothing is impossible. One day, you'll be seeing me in one those gambling tournaments and realize that I'm not even joking. Anything can happen. (4/30/2018 10:14)

#SIMConfession10137
In recent times, there are so many posts on social media where the vigilantes try to take justice into their own hands. But many have forgotten that the gravity of their words can really affect certain people gravely. Here's a little something for everyone so that we can be more mindful of our words or things that we post‚Ä¶ More online.
The pen is mightier than the sword.
Words are like water,
For once spoken, it can never be taken back.
Words cut deeper than any sword would,
For what it hurts are not mortal wounds.
Words can incite or quell,
For its powers are far beyond imaginable.
Words can be tiring to read,
For it‚Äôs tiring to the writer‚Äôs hand as well.
With this, the pen is laid to rest and never be picked up again.
For typing would be far more logical in this day and age.
Alas! The keyboard is mightier than the sword. (4/18/2018 13:05)

text:
With that guys, we have come to our 10,000th confession! As an admin of this page, it's been a honor to help provide SIM students an opportunity and platform to vent, speak out, troll (Unfortunately) and say the things that they really want.
As we move forward, we are seeing if we can do more for the SIM community, so do feel free to PM or comment on this post if you have any suggestions!
Regards
L

#SIMConfession9539: "To #9537. If your family can afford local uni, just go for local uni. I'm a year 3 student and I've seen my friends struggling to find jobs after graduating. Of cos there're those that get lucky immediately after they graduate, but those cases don't exactly start out with high pays(< 3k). My friends who graduated from local uni‚Ä¶ More with a second lower easily found jobs that paid them 3.8k and up in an unrelated sector.
Bottom line, if your family can afford to pay your fees and give you allowances over the next 4 years, go local. If they can't, go UOL, and be prepared to slog like a dog juggling work and studies. "

5. Yes
6. There isn't a first class honours for RMIT but a Pass with Distinction degree should you get a cumulative gpa 3 and above."

#SIMConfession9439: "Reply to #SIMCONFESSIONS9425 Managerial Econs. In my opinion, 2 kinds of people do well for this module:
1) If you like solving puzzles and playing games, you will do well with some effort put into studying.

However with this module, people tend to do either exceedingly well, or disastrously poor with no in-between.
"

#SIMConfession9316 :"Scrolling through the confessions page, I found many in the same position I was a year ago. I have recently started working after spending a year sending out resumes and barely landing any interviews.
I figured I only had myself to blame as I didn't really work hard during my time in UOL and graduated with only third class‚Ä¶ More honours. After spending such a long time unemployed with little to no responses to my applications, I finally landed a job and received an offer of 3k which was higher than what I had expected. I think what had sealed the deal was when the hiring manager asked if I minded doing some admin work for them on the side as well. I readily agreed because a little extra work had sounded far more appealing than the prospect of spending a couple more months unemployed.
So don't give up guys! It might take a long while but it's not impossible to find a job even if your results are less than stellar."

#SIMConfession9256: "I am the OP of #SIMConfession9244.
1. You can try to look for job in JobDB, JobStreet or even Indeed.
2. Let ask yourselves a few questions:
- If a 5.5 day position was offered to you, will you accept it?
- Do you mind to work in ulu areas?
If the answers are YES and NO respectively, I think you can get a job easily. The‚Ä¶ More reason is because Singapore government has set regulations on the ratio Singaporean/PR to Foreigners. Of course, you should indicate that you are a Singaporean/PR. When a HR filters resumes, they will always look at the nationality as they will affect the company's manpower quota.
3. If a HR is interested to hire you, they will contact you within a week. Of course, there are exceptional cases. For instances, their ideal candidate rejected their offer. That is why they offered you. If you did not receive any news within a week, you might want to give a call to people. Sending an email for an update indicates that you are interested in getting this job.
Hope my 2 cents help! :]
"

#SIMConfession9220 :"OP of #SIMConfession9194 here, I have decided to wait awhile more for a possible reply. But in the mean time I'm working on establishing a secondary income instead of applying for other positions. Plus, I'm trying to avoid being in a situation where I accepted and started working in another job and this company send back a‚Ä¶ More reply.
During my schooling years, I had to work PT during my holidays to earn and save up, so as to be used as allowances when school starts. To make as much as possible, I was always in a rush to accept whatever PT that offer me first. And I have been in situations where I started working the first few days of a lower paying job, and to be offered another higher paying job. At that time, due to contract issue, I wasn't able to quit and accept the higher paying job.
I'm also pinning alot of hope on the applied position as its related to my secondary income, and I think I can learn many useful skills to improve (bring in more $$) my secondary income. Cause at the end of the day, in the near future, I want to switch it as my primary instead."

#SIMConfession9118:"let's be real, people. Right now, with the market situation. Don't complain about having low pay, don't overdemand for a high pay. As long as you get a job with a pay above 2000, BE THANKFUL.

Don't compare yourself with people who have a higher starting pay. Maybe their resume is better, maybe their experience is more relevant, maybe their hiring manager likes them more , or maybe it's just luck.
Right now, hang in there. If you found a job, take‚Ä¶ More

#SIMConfession9095: "With regards to the recent posts talking about salaries.
I am a recent graduate in 2015, spent a year after graduation in and out of hospital due to an accident.
Got a full time job doing Operations with a bank this year after i was discharged, earning around 3k - UOL 2nd lower. Have a side line I have been doing since 2010‚Ä¶ More that brings in around 3-4k a month. Total around 6-7k per month on average, pretty no life but economically efficient.
In any case, just ask yourself how badly do you want money and just go all out to get it. Because end of the day, you live your own life and a stupid piece of paper cant determine where you go.
All the best. "

#SIMConfession8972:"It is a fact that the entry level for a local grad as compared to a private one is different.
Using a building as a conparison for our careers.
Having a a local degree is akin to having the access cards to the 2nd or 3rd level of the building.
With a private degree, you might have to start from the ground level.
However it‚Ä¶ More does not mean that the private degree holder cannot climb higher or faster in that building.
He or she could choose to enter the building and work hard finding ways to scale the building, or he could just whine about the unfairness and chooses not to enter the building at all.
It is all about the attitude.
Yes having an advantage is good but what matters is how far you can go.
Stay positive guys.
From a UOL Grad
starting pay at 2.4k earning more tha 4k "

#SIMConfession8971: "It seems like it's that time of the year again where starting pay, selection and hiring is the top negative topic again.
Though I'm from RMIT, let me share my story here.
I, too was a fresh grad 2 years ago. In my first year, I was doing nothing related to HR which was the field I want. Then an opportunity came in the form of‚Ä¶ More a HR part time job. (Not even a full time job, mind you)
But it was from there that I gained the skills, and slowly moved onto a permanent role when it opened. Even so, my pay was way below market rate, only 2.4k but I took it on anyway.
Now I'm earning above 3k, and yes, I may not be earning much, but it was the skills I gained that improved my prospects.
Get out there into the industry and gain relevant skills, expand your network before even thinking about pay. This is fundamental for the first few years in your career.
"

#SIMConfessions8668 #simconfessions8665 oh common, the world is larger than Singapore is. I used my knowlege gained through academic pursuit to find a wife. First I listed down the countries where the female pouplatuon in my age group exceeded the male pouplation. So I had my target countries and I did some elimination (China, Philippines, Vietnam,‚Ä¶ More Singapore). After that I did some profiling when I met women. Based on that I plotted my personality against each women's personality. For the similarities it was easier match. Research shows that if you and your target has 100% similar interestes it wont work out. We get together because of difference and differences are point of sustainable interaction whereas common interests are a point of initial getting together. So while I capitalised on the common interests I also used the difference as a interaction factor. Over time the relationship blossomed and now I am married with a lovely 8 year old daughter. If you need any help finding the right one let me know.

One of these days a paper ball is going to be tossed at your face and‚Ä¶ More swear words in all 4 languages hurled at you, it's just a matter of time. Why are you doing an adult-learners degree when you don't seem to behave like an adult? We're all effin' tired from a whole day at the office and just want to come to class and absorb information to finish our TMAs and ECAs and GBAs in time and move onto the next sem, the last thing we want is to hear your incessant jabber with your friend DURING LECTURE TIME about how you don't understand why girls always think they're fat. Nobody gives a shit. Either leave if you wanna talk so much or just shut up and pay attention. Patience be wearing thin, STFU. /micdrop

#SIMConfessions7925 "In reply to #SIMConfession7920:

After each interview, you must always remember to reflect on yourself i.e.‚Ä¶ More performance, posture and etc. For every of my interviews, I will always think back what I have answered and whether there is/are any better answer(s) to that.
2. In order for you to gain experience in interview, you need lots of exposure. In short, if someone called you for an interview, you should go for it even if you did not apply for it. In‚Ä¶ More

Am I the only who who thinks that this confession page has been misused, abused and spammed beyond salvation? A confession page would share stories, opinions and experiences which are best kept anonymous to protect those directly or indirectly‚Ä¶ More involved in the story.
